NATO Warships Protecting Gaza Convoy Against Israel Attack: Greta Thunberg

Published

Sep 26, 2025 at 05:13 AM EDT

updated

Sep 26, 2025 at 05:23 AM EDT

By Amir Daftari

News Reporter

Newsweek is a Trust Project member

Italy and Spain have deployed naval warships to protect an international flotilla after its organizers reported a series of drone attacks in the Mediterranean. The flotilla, which aims to deliver aid to Gaza, has drawn fierce opposition from Israel and there is a risk the mission could result in a broader confrontation at sea.

Among those onboard the Global Sumud Flotilla (GSF) are lawyers, parliamentarians, activists, and Swedish climate campaigner Greta Thunberg, who has posted warnings on social media about a potentially imminent "deadly" Israeli attack. The coalition of about 50 civilian boats set sail from Barcelona in August, carrying food and medical supplies in an effort to challenge Israels blockade of Gaza.

Newsweek has reached out to the Foreign Ministries of Italy, Spain and Israel for comment.

Why It Matters

The mission comes as the war in Gaza approaches its third year, with aid agencies warning that conditions have become catastrophic. Food, fuel, and medical shortages have left civilians in dire need, and international pressure for relief efforts continues to grow. By sending warships to safeguard the flotilla, Italy and Spain have placed themselves at the center of a mounting humanitarian crisis and a widening dispute with Israel over how aid should reach Gaza.

...

What To Know

The voyage has become increasingly dangerous. Organizers have reported at least a dozen drone strikes in recent weeks, which have damaged several vessels. The most recent incident occurred Tuesday near the Greek island of Crete, when explosions were reported on multiple boats. While no casualties were confirmed, flotilla leaders blamed Israel for the attacks

Earlier, Thunberg shared an Instagram post warning supporters of possible attacks on the flotilla.

View this post on Instagram

A post shared by Greta Thunberg (@gretathunberg)

Spain Deploys Warship

Spain dispatched a naval vessel following the latest strike, citing the need to safeguard its citizens. Around 15 Spaniards are aboard the flotilla. Spanish Prime Minister Pedro Snchez stressed that international law must be upheld and that Spanish nationals have the right to safe passage in the Mediterranean. The decision marks one of Madrids most direct interventions in the Gaza crisis.

...

Italy Sends Two Frigates

Italy responded swiftly as well sending two frigates on Wednesday and Thursday, respectively. Italian Minister of Defense Guido Crosetto condemned the strikes as totally unacceptable and said the ships were dispatched to assist Italian citizens aboard the flotilla.

Prime Minister Giorgia Meloni has criticized the mission as dangerous and irresponsible but widespread protests and strikes across Italy in solidarity with Gaza have put pressure on the government to address the escalating tensions.

Israels Position on the Flotilla

Israel has vowed to block the flotilla from reaching Gaza. Officials argue that any attempt to bypass the naval blockade violates international law and could support Hamas. They maintain that aid can be delivered through Israeli ports under inspection. Organizers counter that the blockade itself is unlawful and deny any ties to extremist groups.

ABBA Abuse

Meanwhile on Thursday, the flotilla reported Abbas Lay All Your Love On Me blasting over their radios. Theyre jamming our radio, GSF member Yasemin Acar said in a video, adding: We dont know where this is coming from, the sound, but other vessels are experiencing the same thing. The GSF blamed Israel for the stunt, which some saw as a pointed reference to Thunbergs Swedish nationality.

...

What People Are Saying

Spanish Prime Minister Pedro Snchez: The government of Spain insists that international law be respected and that the right of our citizens should be respected to sail through the Mediterranean in safe conditions.

Italian Minister of Defense Guido Crosetto: We have sent one ship and another is on its way, ready for any eventuality.

Greta Thunberg: "We call on governments everywhere to fulfill their legal obligation and their complicity in the genocide."

What Happens Next

The flotilla is continuing its journey toward Gaza despite mounting risks. As of Friday (September 26), it is approximately 500 nautical miles from Gaza and organizers expect to arrive within a week. With European warships now in play and Thunberg amplifying warnings of a potential deadly strike, the standoff could soon escalate into a major international flashpoint.
